abstracts.cdata!:
The environmental assessment focuses on
            three main components of the Emergency Reconstruction
            Program Project: agriculture and the use of pesticides;
            housing program; and, private sector development. Potential
            environmental impacts, and the appropriate mitigation
            measures are: 1) provision of agricultural inputs, includes
            activities such as farm machinery for land preparation,
            pesticides and fertilizers, seeds, animal restocking, and
            water pumps for irrigation. While these activities will prod
            agricultural production, improper land management and
            pesticide uses, may induce declining crop yields, and soil
            fertility, and erosion, as well as genetic mutation in
            animals, and cancer, and other health issues on humans. Thus
            it is recommended to eliminate the use of chlorinated
            hydrocarbons in pesticides; avoid excessive fertilizer uses
            to minimize soil erosion, and water contamination; avoid
            importation of plant seed varieties, and animal breeds to
            preserve the local genetic pool, and, select the appropriate
            machinery per soil type, avoiding arid/fragile lands; 2)
            housing construction, and fuel wood collection inevitably
            causes land degradation and soil erosion; therefore, the use
            of corrugated iron sheet roofs, and masonry walls is
            suggested, as is the approach to village forest plantation
            programs, to re-vegetate, and maximize the efficient use of
            fuel wood, since it can not be avoided; and, 3) support for
            enterprise development, predominantly for micro, and small
            enterprises, hence no major environmental adversity is
            foreseen; however, institutional mechanisms should enforce
            environmental regulations, i.e., through the Department of
            the Environment.
